paper_title: Going Deeper into Locally Differentially Private Graph Neural Networks

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Extensive experiments on real-world datasets indicate that UPGNET significantly outperforms existing methods in terms of both privacy protection and learning utility.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The statement attributes a causal effect to using UPGNET: it causes improvements in privacy protection and learning utility relative to baselines, supported by experimental results.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: UPGNET improves privacy protection and learning utility compared with existing methods
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Compared to existing methods, UPGNET significantly improves both privacy protection and learning utility as reported in experiments.
hypotheses.notes: Explicit comparative performance claim with emphasis on 'significantly'; implies statistical testing in the experimental evaluation.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Feature dimension and neighborhood size are the two key factors that affect the utility of privacy-preserving graph learning.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The abstract identifies feature dimension and neighborhood size as the two main factors influencing utility, implying a relationship between these factors and utility.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Describes two factors affecting utility; no explicit directional prediction provided in the abstract.
hypotheses.notes: Identifies influencing factors; further empirical analysis would reveal the direction and magnitude of effects.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The High-Order Aggregator (HOA) layer and the Node Feature Regularization (NFR) layer enhance utility in privacy-preserving graph learning.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: The abstract states that UPGNET enhances utility by introducing HOA and NFR layers, implying a causal impact of these components on utility.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: HOA_layer and NFR_layer increase learning utility compared with not using them
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Two components (HOA and NFR) contribute to improved utility under LDP.
hypotheses.notes: Ablation or component-wise experiments would typically be used to validate the claimed contribution of each layer.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: UPGNET protects user data privacy under local differential privacy (LDP).
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: Described as a privacy-preserving graph learning framework, implying that using UPGNET leads to privacy protection under LDP.
hypotheses.predicted_direction: UPGNET yields higher privacy protection than baselines
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Compared to baseline LDP methods, UPGNET provides improved privacy protection.
hypotheses.notes: Privacy claim contingent on evaluation against baselines; specifics depend on privacy metrics used.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: The three-stage pipeline generalizes the LDP protocols for node features to privacy-sensitive scenarios.
hypotheses.epistemic_justification: A property of the proposed pipeline is that it generalizes LDP protocols for node features to privacy-sensitive contexts, as claimed in the abstract.
hypotheses.specific_type_details: Proposes that the pipeline generalizes LDP protocols to more privacy-sensitive contexts.
hypotheses.notes: Design/generalization claim; would be evaluated by applying the pipeline to privacy-sensitive settings.

processing_notes: Hypotheses were extracted from the abstract and translated into testable statements. Some items are explicit performance claims (H1, H4), others reflect design justifications or identified factors (H3, H2, H5).
